"Do you like my gold ring?"
"Nope, I don't karat all about it."

(That pun was kind of alloying.)

A Wednesday Thursday!

(Solid gold?)

Jim Horne at xwordinfo.com states that this puzzle smashes the record for K's in a puzzle. (The previous record was 18.)  However, this puzzle was 15x16, so Jackson had an extra column to work with!

K's in baseball are strikeouts, and there have never been 24 of them thrown by any pitcher in a single game; the record is 21, in extra innings, and 20 in a regulation nine-inning game.  

Which brings me to a nit that I will pick in another post.
SANKA crossing KAOS was certainly a choice.

Knock knock.
Who‚Äôs there?
The Fab 5.
Who???
Fab 5, I say! I counted 25 K‚Äôs.
But who are the Fab 5???

(Yes I really did that. Counted wrong!)
(Plus obviously don‚Äôt know the song.)
(But it still follows my axiom that more fun is had by making an amusing error.)
Long time solver, first time poster. Nine minutes faster than average on a Wednesday puzzle (which I THOROUGHLY enjoyed). I'll take it and Let's Go Mets!

Here's a baseball nit about a NO-HIT game being [Perfectly pitched]. While this may be close enough for government work (or crosswords), it's not really correct.

There's a name for games that are perfectly pitched, and that is--wait for it--perfect games.

Perfect games are much rarer than no-hitters; there have been 326 no-hitters in major league history, or an average of a bit more than two per season, there have only been 24 perfect games, an average of one every five years.

Perfect games are games when no one on the opposing team reaches base in any way; 27 men up, 27 retired.  In a no-hitter, the opposing team can get on base in several ways:  walks, being hit by a pitch, fielding errors, and even catcher's interference.  In fact, a team that pitches a no-hitter can even lose the game, because any of those runners can score in a number of ways: stolen bases, sacrifices, and other errors, to name the most common.  This has happened twice in MLB history.  (In addition, because the home team doesn't bat in the ninth inning if they're ahead, there were three instances that didn't officially count as no-hitters because the pitchers only pitched eight innings.)

Nobody!‚Äù) and scoffed at the idea of short tennis match being ‚Äòa SET‚Äô (‚ÄúNot a thing!‚Äù). ‚ÄúAsk Magic‚Äù also seemed like a terrible name for an album, but Bruno Mars has sold many more of them than I have, so what do I know.

I don‚Äôt know what made me try putting in numbers to make all of it make sense, but I wish there had been some celebration animation. Because the fact that it worked was pretty exciting.

This puzzle was o‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.K by me.  Not only were there a lot of Ks in the puzzle but so many answers contained multiple Ks that it almost made me dizzy.  There were so many Ks it was like watching a Nolan Ryan NOHIT game.

I‚Äôve enjoyed the puzzles of the last two weeks, which I managed to complete while traveling in Scotland with my wife and step daughter.  We spent time in Edinburgh, Skye and Glasgow (where we spent some time with my daughter and her family) and places in between.  With our busy schedule, I didn‚Äôt have time to peruse the comments, and I missed this community.  It‚Äôs good to be home.

There were 2 places I could have messed up, but the theme saved the day.  Since I'm unfamiliar with Bruno Mars, could he have an album called 14K MAGIK?  Sure, but that wouldn't work today.  

Thanks Jackson, this was a fun one.

Well that was fun. Thought you‚Äôd trip me up with numerals eh? I‚Äôm onto you, you sneaky thing. The Bruno Mars album was played on repeat when DD lived with us so that, along with the FAB 4 was a gimme once I realised rebus wouldn‚Äôt work.

My solving route went as follows.

Early: Hmmm, quite a few K‚Äôs.
Middle: Okay, the theme is about cramming as many K‚Äôs in as possible.  But why?
Two-thirds the way through ‚Äì What can that reveal in the middle be?
At the end ‚Äì Ah, 24 K‚Äôs, perfecto!  

Also perfecto ‚Ä¶ 24K MAGIC was one of my last answers to fill in because I don‚Äôt know the song, and right at the end is the perfect time to uncover a reveal, which ties the whole thing together like a bow.

My favorite answer/clue combo was SICK OUT (a NYT answer debut, and it just sounds so right for what it means), and ‚ÄúAlternative to a strike [cough cough]‚Äù which was delightfully vexing as well as funny.

Another thing I had no trouble with was using numbers in the puzzle. But that's where I fell down. I have no knowledge of Bruno Mars' music or tennis, so when I confidently filled in 14K as my last answer, I thought it was successfully completed. But I solve on paper, so there was no way of knowing that I was wrong until I got here. It never occurred to me to count the number of K's!
ps. You can‚Äôt see a hidden gem. Unless you catch a glimpse of one sparkling, going round and round in the idiomatic washing machine.

My knowledge of Bruno Mars is limited to his once-omnipresent "Uptown Funk", so I had no clue about the name of his album.  But surely the "short tennis match" was going to be 1-SET, so my mind thought, "Perhaps Bruno is a long-distance runner," and tentatively put in 10 K.  
Yes, I was concerned about why the Beatles might be "FAB-0", but who knows what they're called in other parts of the world.

When I was told that something was "amiss" with my grid, I was able to discern the errors of my ways.

24 Ks: an impressive feat for the constructor!
24 Karat: a concerning example about the materialistic nature of our era.

Long before the Titans Clashed, the Pirates visited the Caribbean, or NHL hockey expanded into Seattle, Alfred Tennyson wrote about krakens: Below the thunders of the upper deep; Far, far beneath in the abysmal sea, His ancient, dreamless, uninvaded sleep The Kraken sleepeth: faintest sunlights flee About his shadowy sides: above him swell Huge sponges of millennial growth and height; And far away into the sickly light, From many a wondrous grot and secret cell Unnumber‚Äôd and enormous polypi Winnow with giant arms the slumbering green. There hath he lain for ages and will lie Battening upon huge seaworms in his sleep, Until the latter fire shall heat the deep*; Then once by man and angels to be seen, In roaring he shall rise and on the surface die. Benjamin Britten set this, for tenor and bassoon obbligato, as part of his *Nocturne* (static image, but you wouldn't want to look at a cute drawing of a squid, than a boring album cover): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=19WwXXOm7IM&list=RD19WwXXOm7IM&start_radio=1 *global warming?
Not my favorite.

A truly excessive number of proper noun trivia crossings. And if you don't know one of those proper nouns, then the number cells are very hard to get because numbers in the grid are extremely rare.

I don't find Ray Kroc that obscure considering he was the founder of McDonalds.  I did have a small setback with ibid instead of IDEM.  Generally, IDEM gets abbreviated to id, but Brookes and Bunn really didn't make sense unless it was some new coffee making invention.
I really enjoyed this one. Felt like a good fit for a Wednesday puzzle, difficulty-wise.
I thought it was fun. I was grumbling about all the sports stuff and proper nouns, but I actually ended up getting everything with only a couple of lookups.
Probably a little easier than a typical Wednesday, necessary to make the theme work, but I love the theme - and having knick knack and knock knock in equivalent places in the grid made me smile.

While I really do hate to complain when we fiiiinally having something new and different, I thought the trickery of having numbers was totally wasted on a non-theme. What is ‚Äúmagical‚Äù about having lots of a particular letter in your puzzle? That‚Äôs not difficult to do construction-wise, nor is it clever in any way. 

I would have appreciated this puzzle a lot more if there were a few of these crossed numbers throughout the grid for common phrases‚Ä¶ 2STEP crossed with Y2K and such.

I thought it was a fun grid! Even though I'm not from the US, I got through it without having to look anything up ‚Äì the very first time on a Wednesday!

I'm not familiar with the works of Bruno Mars, but the Beatles' sobriquet and the short Tennis match made me think there might something fun going on here. 

Enjoyable with a twist, I'm looking forward to Jacksons next construction!

As they say in classic films:  "He got me...." [collapses, clutching chest dramatically.]  I guessed the "country duo" person, but the anime style was too much.  (I had to give up IBID, and I've never seen/used "ID EM" --not in any of the dissertations I edited/typed, not in any papers I wrote in college or grad school, so I'll have to look it up.

I also don't feel like counting all the K's in the grid, although I expect I know how many there are....

Those who "know me" will suspect (correctly) that I have never heard a Bruno Mars album.  Or song.  Or Brooks & DUNN.  Or any anime videos/movies/games/books/role-plays.  Or "Nope" show/movie actress.

However, I happened to be at Fernbank Science Center (it was new) at the right time, and I got to hold a MOON ROCK.
I remembered KERRI Strug (inexplicably), and I have heard of RIHANNA, and both AARON and RAY KROC were gimmes.  
So I guess I'm lucky I only had one wrong letter!

A follow-up to my post the other day about streaks. I was out of cell-phone range for 5 days and when I returned, I completed the missing puzzles in order. But alas, the streak was broken. I emailed the NYT Games support staff and they fixed it. The streak is back on! Now 328 and counting! For the record it looks like you can miss up to 3 days and your streak won't be broken as long as you complete the missing puzzles in order. Any more than that and you'll need to contact support. Either way I had an epic hike in the Grand Tetons, and if the price of the trip had been a broken streak, it would have been worth it!

I tend to glance at clues, so I misread fifteen across as "Some garbage jobs." I figured that one would be right up my alley. I remember, for instance, a time when I was required to be a human paperweight on top of a trailer full of trash bound for the dump. I was flying down a highway, splayed face down a few inches from a newspaper, when I realized that I was looking at the obituary of someone I knew and respected. Not the greatest way to find out.

As usual my lack of knowledge about sports, pop culture and the names of actors who played in things I've never seen tripped me up. I had to consult Google several times. But tomorrow is Thursday, my favorite day for the crossword, and I'm looking forward to coming here tomorrow after I've finished and enjoying the usual weeping and outrage. I hope it's a rebus puzzle.

I thought this puzzle was"K" but could not force myself to put the correct #s in the proper boxes. I'm not familiar with his 24KMagic album but I cannot be the only octogenarian who enjoys Bruno's music.
GO HEELS

One of the worst puzzles of all time.
Great debut Jackson. Hope to see more from you.

I LOVED IT AND I DON'T CARE WHO KNOWS IT!

(yep, I loved it enough to obnoxiously use all caps too!)

What a clever puzzle with 24K at the center and discovering 24 K's sprinkled throughout the grid! I thoroughly enjoyed this one. Good luck, Jackson, on the start of your undergrad experience at UNC - I hope you enjoy every moment and that you'll have time to offer us more fun grids!
If the goal was to fit as many natticks as possible to meat an unsatisfactory theme, it was met wonderfully

The clue for 32A is missing an asterisk for 1986, owing to Maradona's infamous "Hand of God" goal against England in the quarter-finals. Of course, these were the days before video review, and they probably would have won the game anyway.

Dunno from Bruno Mars, I thought it might be 24 K MArts. Usually not a fan of numbers in my word puzzles, but this one didn't bother me too much, as 24K is very much "in the language."

In co-ed rec slow-pitch softball I once pitched a 24-hitter, which is the equivalent of a Major League no-hitter. Not really, but a no-hitter in a league like that is extremely rare and indicative of a considerable mismatch.

I really did see Jennie Finch throw a perfect game in professional fast-pitch softball years ago for the Chicago Bandits. More impressive to me was the fact that she stayed after the game to sign autographs, going down the third-base side of the field. 

How many autographs. Hundreds, at least. Maybe thousands. Respect!

I‚Äôm curious: is there anyone here who had never heard of that specific album from ‚ÄúBruno Mars‚Äù but was still able to pick up on the gimmick?

I am generally not a complainer, but this strikes me as the most ridiculous way I have lost a streak to date. I would have no problem here if the crosses (43D and 26D) were expressions that explicitly included numerals in their formulation (e.g. the name of a brand, band, song, movie, etc).

But as this is the case for neither ‚Äúthe fab four‚Äù or ‚Äúa two-set tennis match‚Äù, and given that it is *rare* for an answer to include non-alphabetic characters, IMO the gimmick here was basically a Bruno Mars trivia check. No thanks.

The Edmonton Elks are the city's professional football team playing in the CFL (Canadian Football League.) Warren Moon once played for them back when they were called the Eskimos.

That is to say, 1 Down could have been clued exactly like 67 Across.

26 proper nouns. naticks everywhere. the NE corner was a joke. and adding numerals on top of trivia that were poorly clued.
this is an all-time disaster of a puzzle. just an absolute slog.

I thought it was a good puzzle overall.  I will say if they‚Äôre going to do numeric answers they should do it less rarely so it‚Äôs easier to see as a possibility.

The area I didn‚Äôt like was the left middle.  I thought at the crossing of RACE, ATAD and ACK, ATAD and ACK had multiple plausible answers, and the cross clue that would fix them as one RACE was a huge reach as an answer for Pit A Pat.

Is it not an Elks LODGE, not a club?  Definitely got tripped up by IDEM instead of IBID, but didn't mind the gimmicky theme, that was fine

Delightful puzzle! It was fun seeing all the K words emerging, and although I started typing TWO and FOUR in the rebus blocks, when I figured out the album title, I realized it started with 24K. (I guess Bruno Mars was hoping for a gold album.) 

Lots of things I didn't know in this puzzle, but easy to get with crosses. And really, complainers, part of the fun of doing crossword puzzles is learning bits of trivia, team names, etc. A task can be hard and still be enjoyable.
Loved all the K‚Äôs and the shout out to Kerri Strug who starred in my favorite Olympic moment of all time!

A fresh mind this morning remembered calling the Beatles Fab four, so I tried a rebus FOUR and Autocheck accepted it. So may a short tennis match had only ONE set? No, rejected. But TWO was accepted and got the music. 

Looking back at it later, those rebi/rebuses had been changed to numerals, so presumably twenty-four Karats, not "two four kay." I've seen numerals in crosswords before, as well as other symbols. I was once pretty far along at making a crossword with clues like "Army rank" for a three-blank space which needed to solve to ":el."

üòí TIL that sometimes numbers go in CW puzzles. Good to know. I had to come to the column for this one. On a positive note, I learned some new words today (e.g. robot anime, SICKOUT, IDEM).

Steve,

Not sure why you called this a nit of any kind.

"We all know" the puzzle clue and answer are fine, since they need not cover all cases (or bases) and a [Perfectly pitched] game results in no hits.

"We also all know" that a Perfect Game and a NOHIT game are not the same thing.

IMO this was a Fact Boy post, but a rather self-evident one, not a nit report.

@Peabody

You'd have to say that a perfect game qualifies as a perfectly pitched game.

All the others only MIGHT qualify as a perfectly pitched game, in descending order.  You certainly would not call a run-of-the-mill win a perfectly pitched game.

To put it another way, the Venn diagram of "perfect game" and "perfectly pitched game" is two circles, one on top of another.  They diverge more and more for no-hitters, shutouts and wins.

If your reading ability is fine, then your logic is faulty. It's like saying that the Rockettes are great dancers, and the Rockettes are all women, so women are great dancers.  A no-hitter with eight walks, two hit batsmen and a few balks is not a "perfectly pitched game."

@Barry Ancona

Ask Andrzej, Jane or Helen if they all know.

"Won" could just as easily have been the answer using the guideline you cite.  Every perfect game results in a win.  But you see how absurd the clue is with "Won" as the answer?

I say it's only a little less absurd with NO HIT as the answer.  If a pitcher wins a game, we call it a win; if he pitches a shutout, it's also a win, but we mostly say it's a shutout.  If he pitches a no-hitter, it's usually also a shutout and a win, but we focus on the no-hit part.  And if we say "no-hitter," we specifically mean a non-perfect game, because otherwise, we specify "perfect game."  Which is to say, what delineates the usual usage of "no-hitter" is that it's NOT "perfectly pitched;" if it were, we'd call it a "perfect game."

Anyway, I said from the get-go that it was close enough for crosswords, clued that way in order to make that cutesy little play on words.  Anyone who didn't want to read what I had to say anyway was free to skip over the rest.
